summary: A scientific video series hosted by Professor Jim Caffey that takes viewers on a journey through space, exploring galaxies, planets, and other astronomical concepts.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen that transitions to a stunning view of outer space, showcasing a bright star and a planet with rings, likely Saturn, set against a backdrop of stars. The scene then shifts to a close-up of Earth, highlighting its blue oceans and white clouds, with a bright light source illuminating the planet from the left. The video then moves to a contact information screen featuring a person in a dark polo shirt with a NASA logo, surrounded by social media icons and contact details for Professor Jim Caffey. The next scene introduces a title screen for "10-Minute Astronomy with Professor Jim Caffey," accompanied by images of a comet and a telescope, along with episode details. The video then shows a person wearing headphones and a dark polo shirt, seated in a room filled with various items, including a couch, a dog, and framed pictures on the wall. The person appears to be speaking, with the room's cozy atmosphere and personal touches creating a warm and inviting setting. The video concludes with the person continuing to speak, maintaining the same background and setting throughout.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with an intense and dramatic orchestral piece, evoking a heroic mood. The main voice, a male speaker with an academic tone, starts by introducing himself as "Professor Jim Cathy". He describes the content as "the lecture video for Astronomy, Chapter One" and states that videos will be created for each chapter in every module.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man wearing headphones and a dark blue polo shirt with a white logo, seated in a cluttered room filled with various items, including a dog lying on a red blanket. The room features a couch, a large wall mural, and several framed pictures. The scene transitions to a presentation slide titled "ASTRONOMY Chapter 1 SCIENCE AND THE UNIVERSE: A BRIEF TOUR PowerPoint Image Slideshow," showcasing a book cover labeled "Introduction to Astronomy." The next frame displays an image of two interacting galaxies, captioned "FIGURE 1.1 Distant Galaxies," with a description explaining that the light from these galaxies takes hundreds of millions of years to reach Earth, credited to NASA, ESA, and the Hubble Heritage. The video maintains this image of the galaxies, emphasizing their vast distance and the time it takes for their light to reach us, with the presenter visible in a small inset at the bottom right corner. The presentation continues with the same image and caption, reinforcing the educational content about astronomy and the universe.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker's voice, transitioning directly into a PowerPoint presentation discussing Chapter 1, with the presenter stating "Let's go ahead and jump into the PowerPoint," then "Chapter 1." The speaker mentions "a tour around the universe," then describes colliding galaxies. He details, "when galaxies collide, they...kind of merge into a morph of each other", as well as mentions two spiral galaxies that are "kind of like the Milky Way," and states that the Hubble space telescope captured the picture.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a presentation slide titled "FIGURE 1.2" featuring an image of Mars centered on the Valles Marineris, a complex of canyons as long as the United States. The slide includes a caption explaining the image's focus and credits NASA for the modification. The slide is bordered with a colorful design, and the "openstax" logo is visible in the top right corner. In the bottom right corner, a small inset shows a person in a room, wearing a blue shirt, with a neutral expression, and a background that includes a bookshelf and a desk. The scene transitions to another slide titled "FIGURE 1.3," displaying an image of a colorful nebula with a caption describing it as the remains of a star that exploded in 1954, now visible as the Crab Nebula. The slide credits NASA, ESA, and J. Heiser from Arizona State University. The inset of the person remains in the bottom right corner, maintaining the same neutral expression and background. The video continues with the same slide, "FIGURE 1.3," showing the nebula image and its caption, with the inset of the person unchanged. The video maintains a consistent presentation style, focusing on educational content with visual aids and a small inset of a person in a room.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker discussing a "red planet Mars" mosaic, focusing on Mariner Valley and its canyon-like features. He states the valley is so big it makes the Grand Canyon look tiny and would go across the United States six times deeper. The speaker continues, describing a stellar corpse and how a massive star explodes and dies, referencing the Crab Nebula observed in 1054 by the Chinese, whom he credits as the first observational astronomers. He mentions that the bright stuff seen is gas and heavy elements like calcium and iron, which form what we see in our bodies, bones, and blood. The audio ends with the same speaker starting a new sentence.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a slide titled "FIGURE 1.4" featuring an image of the Orion Nebula, a cloud of cosmic raw material, with accompanying text explaining its composition and distance from Earth. The slide credits NASA, ESA, M. Roberto, and the Hubble Space Telescope Orion Treasury Project Team. The scene then transitions to another slide titled "FIGURE 1.5," showcasing the Hubble Space Telescope in orbit around Earth, with a caption describing it as one of many astronomical instruments in space, credited to the European Space Agency. Throughout the video, a person is visible in the bottom right corner, wearing a blue shirt and sitting in a room with a carpeted floor and a bookshelf in the background. The person appears to be engaged in a presentation or lecture, as indicated by their focused expression and the educational content displayed on the screen. The video maintains a consistent educational atmosphere, with clear and informative visuals complemented by the presenter's presence.
events_list.audio_caption: An individual is speaking in an informative tone about space and astronomy, describing what he deems "the most beautiful thing in the entire night sky", the Orion Nebula. He shares that this is a star-birthing region, stating "stars are born in the forms of human lives". He mentions his past research on the stars within it, before transitioning to the Hubble Space Telescope. The speaker notes that it will be replaced soon and explains that it was named after Edwin P. Hubble, an American astronomer from Marshfield, Missouri. He mentions the local recognition in the speaker's community, including a one-third scale replica in the town square.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a blue shirt sitting in a room, with a large screen behind him displaying educational content. The screen initially shows an image of Earth from space, labeled "FIGURE 1.6" and titled "Humanity's Home Base." The image depicts the Western hemisphere, with text explaining that the view is from 35,400 kilometers above Earth, combining data from two satellites. The man appears to be presenting or discussing the image. The screen then transitions to "FIGURE 1.7," showing a scaled-down representation of Earth and the Moon, with the caption "Earth and Moon, Drawn to Scale." The man continues to engage with the audience, likely explaining the content on the screen. The environment suggests an educational or presentation setting, with the man actively involved in delivering information about Earth and its celestial neighbor.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker describing Earth, referring to it as the "pale blue dot" and explaining that the image is from a geostationary satellite, which is used for communication, TV broadcasts, and weather satellites. He speaks in an informative and somewhat educational tone. He then describes what it would look like to scale the earth and the moon together, mentioning the distance and size differences.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a slide titled "FIGURE 1.7" from OpenStax, featuring an image of Earth and the Moon drawn to scale, with a caption explaining that the image shows Earth and the Moon to scale for both size and distance, credited to NASA. The slide is bordered with a colorful design, and a small inset in the bottom right corner shows a person in a room, possibly a classroom or office, with a neutral expression. The video then transitions to "FIGURE 1.8," another OpenStax slide, depicting the solar system with the Sun, planets, and dwarf planets drawn to scale. The caption notes that the orbits of the planets are much more widely separated than shown in the drawing, emphasizing the size of Earth compared to the giant planets, also credited to NASA. The inset of the person remains in the bottom right corner, maintaining a neutral expression. The video continues to display "FIGURE 1.8" without any changes, maintaining the same visual elements and captions, with the inset of the person still present. The video concludes with the same slide, "FIGURE 1.8," and the inset of the person, with no further changes or transitions.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker describing the "entire solar system family," including the four small planets, the four gas giants, and dwarf planets like Pluto and Ceres, with a calm and informative tone. He mentions that Ceres used to be an asteroid and Pluto used to be the ninth planet, and adds that Pluto is now a dwarf planet. At the end, we hear a quiet, ambient sound of whooshing, adding a sense of the vastness of space.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a slide titled "FIGURE 1.9" from OpenStax, featuring an image of a spiral galaxy, NGC 1073, with a caption explaining its similarity to the Milky Way Galaxy. The slide is set against a white background with a green header and a yellow border. The galaxy image is detailed, showing a bright central region and spiral arms filled with stars. A small inset image of a person appears in the bottom right corner, likely the presenter. The scene transitions to another slide titled "FIGURE 1.10," which displays a photograph of the Milky Way Galaxy as seen from Earth, with a caption describing its appearance as a cross-section of stars and dust. The background of this slide is also white, with a green header and a yellow border. The presenter's inset image remains in the bottom right corner. The video concludes with the presenter's image still visible, indicating a continuous presentation flow.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker describing a spiral galaxy, noting that it's "probably a barred spiral galaxy," with blue and white areas indicating gas and stars forming, and dark lanes of dust. The speaker explains that gas and dust make up the ingredients for new stars. Following his description, there is a distinct clicking sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a still image of a person standing in a desert landscape, silhouetted against a vibrant sunset. The sky is filled with stars, showcasing the Milky Way Galaxy, which is described in the accompanying text as a cross-sectional view of the galaxy's disk, visible as a milky white avenue of stars with dark rifts of dust. The text, labeled "FIGURE 1.10," credits Ian Norman for the image, which is part of the OpenStax educational material. The person in the image is wearing dark clothing and appears to be gazing at the sky. In the bottom right corner of the frame, there is a small inset video of a man in a room, who seems to be speaking or presenting, although his face is not clearly visible. The overall atmosphere of the video is educational and serene, with a focus on the beauty of the night sky and the Milky Way.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker describing an image, "a long time-lapse image of the Milky Way Galaxy," and contrasting the visibility of the galaxy based on location, mentioning cities with light pollution versus the desert of Arizona and Kitt Peak National Observatory. He expresses awe at the sight, emphasizing how different it is from a place like the Las Vegas strip. The clip ends with a brief static sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a presentation slide titled "FIGURE 1.11" from OpenStax, showcasing an image of the star cluster M9, which contains approximately 250,000 stars. The slide includes a description of the cluster, mentioning its visibility from space and its distance of roughly 25,000 light-years away, credited to NASA and ESA. The image of the star cluster is displayed prominently on the right side of the slide, with a dense collection of stars visible against the dark backdrop of space. In the bottom right corner, there is a small inset video of a person, presumably the presenter, who appears to be explaining the content of the slide. The presenter is wearing a blue shirt and is seated in a room with a cluttered background, including various items on shelves and a desk. The overall atmosphere of the video is educational, with the presenter likely providing context and insights about the star cluster M9.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a "globular star cluster," mentioning that they have hundreds of millions of stars and are spherical in shape. He notes that they are old stars surrounding the Milky Way galaxy.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a series of educational slides from an astronomy presentation, each accompanied by a small inset of a person in a casual setting, likely explaining the content. The first slide, labeled "FIGURE 1.12," displays an image of the Atacama Large Millimeter/Submillimeter Array (ALMA) telescopes in the Atacama Desert of northern Chile, with the caption "Neighbor Galaxies," highlighting the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds. The second slide, "FIGURE 1.13," shows the Andromeda galaxy (M31), described as the closest spiral galaxy to our Milky Way, with the caption "Closest Spiral Galaxy." The third slide, "FIGURE 1.14," presents the Fornax Cluster of Galaxies, located 60 million light-years away, with the caption "Fornax Cluster of Galaxies." Throughout the video, the presenter, visible in the inset, appears engaged and animated, using hand gestures to emphasize points. The background of the slides is consistent, with a white background and a colorful border, while the inset shows a room with various items, suggesting a home or office environment. The video transitions smoothly between slides, maintaining a focus on the educational content and the presenter's explanations.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing looking at galaxies using millimeter light and radiation. He mentions cold hydrogen with 21-centimeter radiation, using radio telescopes to view a group of radio telescopes in Chile looking at nearby minor galaxies. He shifts focus to the nearest galaxy, Andromeda, calling it a "great Andromeda galaxy," twice the size of the Milky Way. He notes that the Milky Way and Andromeda are coming together, and someday they will collide. He pivots to discussing the Fornax cluster galaxies and speaks of "look back time," looking back in the history of the universe to see how galaxies used to be, adding everything in the picture is a galaxy.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a presentation slide titled "FIGURE 1.15" from a source labeled "openstax." The slide displays a calendar-like chart with months from January to December, each representing a different stage in cosmic history, such as the Big Bang, Galaxy Formation, and the arrival of humans. The chart is accompanied by a detailed explanation of cosmic time, with specific dates highlighted in teal to mark significant events. The text below the chart provides context and credits for the modifications made by various contributors, including NASA, ESA, and others. In the bottom right corner, a man wearing a dark shirt is visible, seemingly engaged in presenting or discussing the content. The background of the slide is white, with a clean and organized layout, and the overall atmosphere is educational and informative. The video maintains a consistent focus on the slide's content, with no significant changes or movements observed between frames.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker with an informative tone. He explains how different events would occur on a calendar year if the entire timeframe of the universe was shrunk down. He states that the Big Bang would be on January 1st, the Milky Way would form in May, our solar system would start to form around September, and the first complex life forms would come in November. He also specifies that dinosaurs came on Christmas day and went extinct on the 30th. Then finally, in the last few hours of the last day, humans appeared.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a white screen displaying the OpenStax logo and a copyright notice, indicating that the content is licensed under a Creative Commons BY 4.0 International license. The scene transitions to a person wearing a headset and a dark blue polo shirt with a triangular logo, sitting in a room with a couch, a lamp, and various items scattered around. The person appears to be speaking, as indicated by their hand gestures and the presence of a microphone. The video then shifts to another individual wearing a maroon hoodie with a large "M" and the word "Missouri" on it, also wearing a headset and speaking in a room decorated with posters, a lamp, and a television. Text appears on the screen, asking viewers if they enjoyed the episode and if they want to see more content. The person in the maroon hoodie continues to speak, and additional text appears, inviting viewers to check out other videos and mentioning that the channel has been monetized. The video concludes with the person in the maroon hoodie still speaking, with the room's background remaining consistent throughout the sequence.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker expressing gratitude for joining a video lecture. A different male speaker is then heard promoting a YouTube channel, inviting viewers to watch more videos and subscribe. Finally, the clip ends with a polite expression of thanks from the speaker.
